summary: This document is a chain of internal U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) emails from August 20, 2019, discussing how to handle document requests from Jeffrey Epstein's defense lawyers following his death. The requests are made under the Department of Justice's Touhy regulations. The emails indicate the criminal case is being terminated via a nolle prosequi order and that the matter should be referred to the Civil Division.

events.title: Epstein Defense Team Submits Touhy Requests
events.description: Epstein's lawyers, led by Michael Miller, send document requests to the SDNY, MCC, and FBI under DOJ Touhy regulations, seeking information related to Epstein's death.

events.title: Termination of US v. Epstein Criminal Case
events.description: The government has submitted a proposed order of nolle prosequi (dismissal) for the criminal case US v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 0490, which will terminate the proceeding.

events.title: Internal SDNY Coordination on Epstein Requests
events.description: SDNY prosecutors internally discuss and decide to refer the post-death document requests from Epstein's estate to the Civil Division, as the criminal case is ending.

keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019, his defense lawyers immediately began submitting formal document requests to the SDNY, MCC, and FBI under Touhy regulations, seeking information related to his death.
The SDNY prosecutors state that the government has submitted a proposed order of nolle prosequi, which will formally terminate the criminal case US v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 0490.

SDNY prosecutors internally determine that the post-death document requests do not arise under criminal discovery rules (Rule 16) and should be handled by the Civil Division, not the criminal prosecutors.
The email chain reveals coordination within the U.S. Attorney's Office to assign a specific AUSA from the Civil Division to handle all future Epstein-related Touhy requests.
The defense legal team making the requests includes several attorneys from Steptoe & Johnson LLP, including Michael C. Miller, Martin G. Weinberg, and others.
